Text.Text: Good t'see ye made it through th'attack - the whole town's been talkin' 'bout yer bravery.  Ye be needing a place to rest after all th' fightin'?
'Ave ye not 'eard?  There's goblins at the docks!  We be needing all the blades we can muster, or our corpses'll be floating on Maer Dualdon!
Being tired's less a worry than being dead, so damn ye and yer weariness - there's a fight to be won!  Now git to the docks and show those goblins what iron yer made of!
Ye filthy dog, if we live through this, I'll see t'it ye eat those words.  Ulbrec *ordered* me to remain here in case of an attack so that the Guard had a place to retreat to.
Now who might y'be t'come sweeping through the doors of the Widow?  One of a fresh crop o' sell-swords from the south?
Why, there's plenty of coin to be had spilling goblin blood.  How is it ye've come to Targos with steel in hand and not caught word of th'filthy little rats?
They've been picking at Targos' walls like vultures, and it's got Lord Ulbrec worried.  'Goblin's tread speaks a bad season ahead,' the saying goes - and this time's no different.
Aye, lodgings I have a-plenty - 'cept for the barred room a-stairs.  Take y'pick of the lot, and if the price's agreeable, th' room's yours.
Never y'mind 'bout that.  It's got the strings of a sad bard's song, and there's no cause to be weighing down yer shoulders with such talk.

A woman passed away in that room long ago.  She was waiting for her man to return from Dualdon, but he was lost in a storm... and the poor woman hurled herself from the window upstairs to the cliffs below.
Ye can still hear her weeping at night, and I've had the room warded out of respect to her grief.  A sad tale, to be sure.  If there was anything I could do to help her, I would.
Well, the inn's named the Weeping Widow, but th'part about that poor woman flinging herself from the window tends to send lodgers packing right-quick.

Truly?  Then here's the key to the room - it should get ye past the ward on the door.  If ye can help set that poor woman's spirit at ease, I'd be grateful, so I would.  Her weeping can be heard mostly at night, so that would probably be the best time to catch sight of her.
Long story, friend - had a priest of Myrkul staying here, and he scratched the thing on the door.  Didn't do a lick of good, it didn't.
*Aye,* Koluhm - cursed be his name -  he just up and left without leaving a single coin for his stay!

Oh, *aye,* I know that twisted hound's get, I do!  Had a room here for two nights, he did, then said he couldn't bear the weeping of the spirit, so he up and left without so much as shelling out a single coin for the room!

Aye... well, with nothing that matters, he didn't!  He put some glyph on the door of the room upstairs to keep the spirit inside, but that doesn't *stop* her weeping now, does it?  If anything, it's gotten worse since that damn thing was placed on it!
Hells if I know - torture me ears, most-like.  At least it keeps people from wandering in there.  My key still works, though.

Aye... well, no, he gave me some damnable "magic potion," some concoction or another, but he wouldn't even tell me what it was, only that it was "more than enough for the room."  Truth be told, I'm too scared to open it, let alone drink it.
Oh, nay - I don't want a priest of Myrkul getting mad at me, I don't.  He'd probably lay a curse on me grave or turn me into a zombie, he would - nay, I'm willing to let it go.
Here ye are... can ye make heads or tails of it?

Well... hmm.  All right.  If ye can't figure it out, perhaps one of the priests or mages in town would know what the damn thing is - or better yet, that wife of Lord Ulbrec, Elytharra, she'd probably know what it is.  She's an enchantress, hear tell.
Just head out o' the Weeping Widow, head east over the bridge, then up north a little ways to the Town Hall.  Ye can find her and Lord Ulbrec there.
All hail, the sell-sword of Targos 'as returned!  How can I help ye this day?
The weeping widow, then?  What 'bout her?
Nay...!  Truly?!  A bringer of miracles, ye are, and blessed am I for y'efforts - thank ye, friend!  Thank ye greatly!
Eh... now, can ye really put a price on a soul's peace and an innkeeper's thanks?  It's the doing of good works that brings ye the biggest payoff at the end of the road, so it does.
Hmmm.  Seems t'me there's a powerful set o' ethics at work somewhere.  I'm grateful for it, for one.
Hmm... well, then, here ye are - all's my purse can spare, friend.  And thanks again for yer help.
I shall speak well of ye, I shall - everyone in Targos'll soon know how much ye've helped me.  Thank ye again, friend!  A helpful hand in these difficult times is worth its weight in gold.
Ye had any luck setting that poor woman's heart to rest?  Every hour she's here rattles me nerves... if anything, her weeping's gotten worse since ye arrived.
A ghost-touched bottle?  But - what of the potion inside?

That damned priest, I knew it was worthless!  Hhrmm... well, thank ye for yer efforts, but I'd rather such a thing be kept far from me.  I'd sooner keep anything touched by spirits away from me, I would.
Well, perhaps the Lady Elytharra could shed some light on how it might be used.  She's said to be an enchantress of some skill.
At the least, she could take it off yer hands, but that would be between the two o' ye.  Ye can find her in the Town Hall, just to the east of here, if ye don't know the way already.
Eh... hmmm.  Well, now, ye offered to take a look at it, didn't ye?  If I'd known that ye'd want to be *paid,* that'd be a different matter.
All right!  All right!  Hmmph... here ye are.  And, eh, if ye can't find a place to spend it in town, ye can always bring that gold back 'ere, and I've got a room for ye.

A fisherman... name o' Donovan, I think.  A little thick in the skull, but a solid enough fellow.  Big-hearted.  Spent most of his nights down at the Salty Dog.  He lost himself in a storm on Maer Dualdon, drowned hisself, most-like.
Well, no, not that I heard.  By most reckoning, he'd drowned.  He probably had one too many tankards, and with the rough weather on the lake during the storms, well... ye can guess what happened.
Well, there's wrecks scattered across the bed of Maer Dualdon, and pieces of them wash up now and again.  If ye knew the name of the ship, mayhap a piece turned up somewheres?
Gohar, the barkeep down at the Salty Dog would most-like know the name - he has enough pieces of ships hanging from the rafters of the Dog, he does.

Well, now, it'd pain me to do so, but I'd have to charge ye for the stay... and I don't fancy middle of the night wake up calls, so ye'd need to wake yourself up.  Ye might need to sleep a stretch or two in the room upstairs before night falls, I'm thinking.
Aye... well, with nothing that matters, he didn't!  He put some glyph on the door of the room upstairs to keep the spirit inside, but that didn't do much good, did it?
Hells if I know - all it did was keep people from wandering in there.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could tame this spirit - perhaps banish her.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... there might be something I can do to help her.  I could look into the matter, if you want.
I've come to speak to you about the ghost that haunts the upstairs of your inn.
I wanted to know if you knew of any work to be found in Targos.
Do you know a priest named Koluhm?  He's said to have a room here.
Do you know a priest of Myrkul named Koluhm?  He said he had a room here.
We identified that potion Koluhm gave you.  It's a ghost-touched bottle.
I'm in need of a room, yes.
I'm in need of a room, yes.
Nothing at the moment.  Farewell.
I'm in need of rest - I can't press on anymore.
Ah, that would explain why you're here guarding the Weeping Widow... see you at the docks, "defender of Targos."
To the docks, then.  Farewell.
Ah, that would explain why you're here guarding the Weeping Widow... see you at the docks, "defender of Targos."
To the docks, then.  Farewell.
And a fine job you're doing... well away from the battle.  To the docks, then.  Farewell.
Perhaps.  Do you know of any work to be found in town?
Do you know a priest named Koluhm?  He's said to have a room here.
Do you know a priest of Myrkul named Koluhm?  He said he had a room here.
Just a traveler in need of a place to rest.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
I've already had an encounter with the goblin raiders.  What do you know of them?
What can you tell me about that spirit that haunts the room upstairs?
Do you know a priest named Koluhm?  He's said to have a room here.
Do you know a priest of Myrkul named Koluhm?  He said he had a room here.
We identified that potion Koluhm gave you.  It's a ghost-touched bottle.
Actually, I'm just looking for a place to rest at the moment.
Actually, I'm just looking for a place to rest at the moment.
Perhaps we'll discuss this another time.  Farewell.
What can you tell me about that spirit that haunts the room upstairs?
Do you know a priest named Koluhm?  He's said to have a room here.
Do you know a priest of Myrkul named Koluhm?  He said he had a room here.
We identified that potion Koluhm gave you.  It's a ghost-touched bottle.
I'm looking for a place to rest.  Do you have a free room?
I'm looking for a place to rest.  Do you have a free room?
Perhaps we'll discuss this another time.  Farewell.
What's wrong with the barred room?
I'd like to hear it... especially if I'm going to be staying here.
If it has the makings of a bard's song, then I'd like to judge for myself.
If you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could put the woman's soul at peace.
If you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could put the woman's soul at peace.
If you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could tame this spirit - perhaps banish her.
There might be something I can do to help her.  I could look into the matter, if you want.
So Koluhm couldn't bear the weeping and left without paying?
Why didn't you mention this at the start?
Very well.  Let me see what rooms you have available.
Do you know of any work to be found in Targos?
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
If you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could put the woman's soul at peace.
If you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could put the woman's soul at peace.
If you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could tame this spirit - perhaps banish her.
There might be something I can do to help her.  I could look into the matter, if you want.
So Koluhm couldn't bear the weeping and left without paying?
Very well.  Let me see what rooms you have available.
Do you know of any work to be found in Targos?
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
Ward on the door?  What ward?
Can we rest here until night, then?
Very well.  I'll need to rest first, to gather my strength.
Hmmm.  It's nighttime right now.  Perhaps I'll go see what I can do.
I'll see what I can do.  Farewell.
Priest of Myrkul - you mean Koluhm?  I've heard of him.
Priest of Myrkul - you mean Koluhm?  He said he stayed here for a while.
I see.  Well, if the spirit comes out only at night, can we rest here until nightfall?
Very well.  Let me see what rooms you have available.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
Weeping?  What weeping?
Koluhm didn't pay you for the room?
So he didn't pay you *anything?*  Are you sure?
Weeping?  What weeping?
Koluhm didn't pay you for the room?
So he didn't pay you *anything?*  Are you sure?
Koluhm didn't pay you for the room?
What was the glyph supposed to do?
So that's all Koluhm did - just put the glyph on the door?
Why didn't you take the matter to Lord Ulbrec or the Guard?  I'm sure they would have made Koluhm pay the gold he owed you.
Could I see this potion?
Could I see this potion he gave you?
Not sure; it does seem magical, though.  If you want, we could try to identify it for you.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could tame this spirit - perhaps banish her.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... there might be something I can do to help her.  I could look into the matter, if you want.
I'll see about getting the bottle identified, then.  Before I go, though, I'm in need of a room.
I'll see about getting the bottle identified, then.  Before I go, though, I'm in need of a room.
Do you know where I can find any work in town?
Where can we find Elytharra?
Very well.  We'll seek her out, then.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could tame this spirit - perhaps banish her.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... there might be something I can do to help her.  I could look into the matter, if you want.
I'll do that, then.  Before I go, though, I'm in need of a room.
I'll do that, then.  Before I go, though, I'm in need of a room.
Do you know where I can find any work in town?
Very well.  We'll seek her out, then.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, I might be able to put the woman's soul at peace.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... if you allow me to examine the room, perhaps I could tame this spirit - perhaps banish her.
About that weeping spirit in the upstairs room... there might be something I can do to help her.  I could look into the matter, if you want.
I've come to speak to you about the ghost that haunts the upstairs of your inn.
I wanted to know if you knew of any work to be found in Targos.
Do you know a priest named Koluhm?  He's said to have a room here.
Do you know a priest of Myrkul named Koluhm?  He said he had a room here.
We identified that potion Koluhm gave you.  It's a ghost-touched bottle.
Let me see what rooms you have available.
Let me see what rooms you have available.
Nothing at the moment.  Farewell.
I put that woman's spirit at ease; you shouldn't hear any more weeping from now on.
We dealt with that spirit from the room upstairs; it shouldn't give you any more trouble.
We have... subdued... the spirit from the room upstairs; it shouldn't give you any more trouble.
She seems to be waiting for her husband - do you know who that might be?
Can you tell me about Veira's husband again?
Who put that ward on the door of her room?
If the spirit comes out only at night, can we rest here until nightfall?
What can you tell me about her?
Never mind.  I was more interested in a room.
Never mind.  I was more interested in a room.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
Your thanks is worth its weight in gold... if you understand my meaning.
It pleased me to help you and the spirit - no thanks are necessary.
That's a fine sentiment, but gold is the language I speak.
That seems to be the case throughout the Realms, from Baldur's Gate to Icewind Dale.  I wonder if that happens throughout the Planes.
You're right - we'll consider it an act of good faith, then.
Ethics don't buy you new arrows, so I'd be grateful if you handed over some gold.
You're right - we'll consider it an act of good faith, then.
Do you have a room available?  I am in need of rest.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
It was no trouble - but do you have a room available?  I am in need of rest.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
I put that woman's spirit at ease; you shouldn't hear any more weeping from now on.
We dealt with that spirit from the room upstairs; it shouldn't give you any more trouble.
We have... subdued... the spirit from the room upstairs; it shouldn't give you any more trouble.
She seems to be waiting for her husband - do you know who that might be?
Can you tell me about Veira's husband again?
What can you tell me about her?
Not yet, but we identified that potion Koluhm gave you.  It's a ghost-touched bottle.
No, but I am in need of rest first.
Is there any other work to be found in Targos?
I'm still working on the matter.  Farewell.
There was only water inside.  Only the bottle itself is enchanted.
Only the bottle was enchanted.  It's supposed to be able to hold pieces of the ethereal plane inside... but there was only water inside, not a potion.
Do you know who might be interested in it?
Actually, we already went to a great deal of trouble to get it identified.  Some gold would make the trouble worthwhile.
Very well, then.  Farewell.
I'm glad I could help clear up the nature of the bottle, then.  Farewell.
Actually, we already went to a great deal of trouble to get it identified.  Some gold would make the trouble worthwhile.
I'm glad I could help.  Perhaps the Lady Elytharra can see the use in such a bottle.  Farewell.
I'm glad I could help.  Perhaps the Lady Elytharra can see the use in such a bottle.  Farewell.
Well, then, maybe we'll just hide the ghost-touched bottle somewhere in the inn.  Who knows?  Perhaps it attracts ghosts and undead.
Well, then, maybe we'll just hide the ghost-touched bottle somewhere in the inn.  Who knows?  Perhaps it attracts ghosts and undead.
Well, then, maybe we'll just hide the ghost-touched bottle somewhere in the inn.  Who knows?  Perhaps it attracts ghosts and undead.
I don't want to argue with you - I just want to be paid for my trouble.
I don't want to argue with you - I just want to be paid for my trouble.
I don't want to argue with you - I just want to be paid for my trouble.
Never mind, then.  Farewell.
We'll see.  Farewell.
I see.  So his body never turned up?
Never mind, then.  Let me see what rooms you have available.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
What about his ship?
Never mind, then.  Let me see what rooms you have available.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
Who would know the name of the ship?
I'll look into later.  For now, let me see what rooms you have available.
Hmm.  Thanks for the information.  Farewell.
I may go see Gohar, then.  Before I go, let me see what rooms you have available.
Hmm.  Thanks for the information.  Farewell.
I see.  You said something about a ward on the door upstairs?
Ever the businessman, I see.  We'll rest now, then.
Perhaps I'll simply wander the town until night falls.  Farewell, Cahl-Hyred.
What was the glyph supposed to do?
So that's all Koluhm did - just put the glyph on the door?
